title: IngressNightmare: Critical Kubernetes RCE Chain Exposing 43% of Cloud Environments (CVSS 9.8)
affected_products: Any cloud provider with custom ingress-nginx installations

timeline.event: Wiz Research reports CVE-2025-1974 and CVE-2025-24514 to Kubernetes security team
Kubernetes removes NGINX configuration validation from admission controller
Kubernetes sends embargo notifications regarding the five vulnerabilities
Public disclosure and patched versions (1.12.1, 1.11.5) released
Unit42 reports active scanning and exploitation attempts in the wild

simple_summary.what_happened: A series of critical vulnerabilities dubbed IngressNightmare were discovered in the Ingress NGINX Controller for Kubernetes. The most severe, CVE-2025-1974 (CVSS 9.8), allows unauthenticated remote code execution through the admission webhook. When chained with other annotation injection flaws, attackers can achieve complete cluster takeover without any authentication.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Over 40% of Kubernetes administrators use ingress-nginx, making this one of the most impactful Kubernetes vulnerabilities to date. Research identified over 6,500 clusters including Fortune 500 companies with publicly exposed vulnerable admission controllers. Any organization running Ingress NGINX Controller versions below 1.11.5 or version 1.12.0 is at risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker identifies a vulnerable Ingress NGINX Controller with exposed admission webhook. Step 2: Sends a malicious Ingress object containing crafted NGINX configuration directives. Step 3: The admission controller processes and validates the configuration using the NGINX binary. Step 4: Injected directives execute arbitrary code during the validation phase. Step 5: Attacker gains access to the controller's service account which by default can read all secrets cluster-wide. Step 6: Exfiltrates secrets (API keys, credentials, certificates) leading to complete cluster compromise.
what_you_should_do: Immediately upgrade to Ingress NGINX Controller version 1.12.1 or 1.11.5
Lock down network access to the admission webhook - only allow Kubernetes API Server
If unable to upgrade, disable the ValidatingWebhookConfiguration named ingress-nginx-admission
Reduce the controller's service account privileges to minimum required
Review cluster logs for suspicious admission webhook requests
Rotate all secrets if you were running vulnerable versions exposed to untrusted networks
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Ingress NGINX Controller is a core Kubernetes component with over 18,000 GitHub stars, serving as the gateway between external traffic and internal services. The default installation grants the controller access to ALL secrets across ALL namespaces. Successful exploitation gives attackers the keys to the entire kingdom - credentials, API keys, certificates, and the ability to deploy malicious workloads. Active exploitation attempts have been observed in the wild.

tactics.description: Attackers target exposed Ingress NGINX admission webhook endpoints
Arbitrary code execution through malicious NGINX configuration directives
Deploying malicious workloads using stolen credentials
Accessing Kubernetes secrets using the controller's service account
Using stolen service account tokens to access other cluster resources
Exfiltrating secrets and sensitive data from Kubernetes cluster

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for suspicious HTTP requests to the ingress-nginx admission webhook endpoint. Look for unusual Ingress objects with malicious annotation patterns and unexpected process spawning from the controller pod.

log_sources.description: Ingress object creation/modification events and admission webhook calls
Configuration validation events and error messages
HTTP traffic to admission webhook endpoint (typically port 8443)
Process execution events from ingress-nginx pods
Secret access patterns from ingress controller service account

what_to_look_for.indicator: Malicious annotation patterns in Ingress objects
what_to_look_for.description: Ingress objects with suspicious nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io annotations containing code injection
what_to_look_for.log_field: spec.metadata.annotations containing shell commands or lua_code

what_to_look_for.description: Admission webhook requests from non-API-server sources
Ingress controller service account accessing secrets in unusual namespaces
Unexpected child processes (sh, bash, curl, wget) from nginx-ingress-controller
what_to_look_for.log_field: Process creation events from ingress-nginx container

what_to_look_for.description: Repeated requests to /healthz or webhook endpoints from external IPs
what_to_look_for.log_field: High volume requests to admission webhook from single IP

immediate_actions.description: Identify the current version of your ingress-nginx deployment
If unable to upgrade, disable the admission webhook
Verify the admission webhook is not exposed externally
immediate_actions.command: kubectl get svc -n ingress-nginx ingress-nginx-controller-admission -o yaml

immediate_actions.description: Check for suspicious Ingress objects created recently
immediate_actions.command: kubectl get ingress --all-namespaces -o json | jq '.items[] | select(.metadata.annotations | keys[] | contains("nginx"))'

immediate_actions.description: Review Kubernetes audit logs for unusual secret access by ingress controller
